   vent dependence transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.

   Piperacillin - [**2115-4-12**] 02:07 AM
   Infusions:

   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

C (97.9

C (97.9

   BP: 106/49(63) {96/46(59) - 134/73(88)} mmHg
   RR: 14 (14 - 24) insp/min

   PIP: 21 cmH2O
   Plateau: 18 cmH2O
   SpO2: 99%
   ABG: 7.40/44/433//2
   Ve: 5.8 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 866
   Physical Examination
   General Appearance: No acute distress, chronically ill
   Eyes / Conjunctiva: No(t) PERRL, left pupil 4->2mm. unable to close
   left eye.
   Head, Ears, Nose, Throat: Normocephalic, Poor dentition, trach in
   place. Dry mucous membranes
   Cardiovascular: (S1: Normal), (S2: Normal, Widely split )
   Peripheral Vascular: (Right radial pulse: Present), (Left radial pulse:
   Present), (Right DP pulse: Present), (Left DP pulse: Present)
   Respiratory / Chest: (Expansion: Symmetric), (Percussion: Resonant :
   anteriorly), (Breath Sounds: Diminished: at bases), vent water
   obscuring but otherwise clear anteriorly
   Abdominal: Non-tender, Distended, bowel sounds sluggish. Firm stool
   filled colon,  heparin shot bruises
   Extremities: Right: Trace, Left: Trace, No(t) Cyanosis
   Musculoskeletal: Unable to stand, flexion contractures at ankles
   Skin:  Cool, 1.5x1.5 sacral pressure ulcer/skin tear
   Neurologic: No(t) Attentive, No(t) Follows simple commands, Responds
   to: Noxious stimuli, Movement: No spontaneous movement, No(t) Sedated,
   No(t) Paralyzed, Tone: Normal, right CN VII palsy. Left corneal reflex
   intact. Tongue deviated to left. DTR trace in biceps, patellars.
   Labs / Radiology
   272 K/uL
   9.7 g/dL
   4.7 mEq/L
   30.1 %
   13.5 K/uL
        [image002.jpg] PENDING
                             [**2115-4-11**]  09:56 PM
                             [**2115-4-11**]  10:12 PM
   WBC
   13.5
   Hct
   30.1
   Plt
   272
   TropT
   0.39
   TCO2
   28
   Other labs: CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:258/12/0.39
   Microbiology: Bcx and ucx on admission NGTD
   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. currently gas exchanging well on current vent settings.
   recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and
   inability to clear secretions.
   - blood, sputum cultures
   - empiric VAP therapy for now if no cultures + at 48 hours will
   discontinue (vanc/zosyn/cipro)
   - chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - wean FIO2 by O2sats
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  Had
   extensive neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing
   including LP, paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP,
   MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient
   does not appear to be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to
   noxious stimuli and appears to calm when addressed
   - Neuro consult in AM
   - Continue dilatin at prior dosing
   - Could pursue LP although MS appears similar to that in [**Month (only) 1563**] based on
   OMR, and LP at that time was unrevealing
   # Vomiting: Unable to assess pain currently given altered mental
   status. Abdominal exam most notable for distension and firm stool
   filled colon in LLQ. KUB showing air throughout colon without evidence
   obstruction.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG this AM
   - Complete r/o MI this morning
   - Continue aspirin
   - Once rules out can d/c plavix
   # Acute renal failure: Likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of
   poor intake.  Patient appears dry on exam.  Chronically with foley so
   unlikely obstruction.
   - Will trend Cr
   - IVF
   - Renally dose meds
    # Anemia: Currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Currently normotensive although in the setting of
   dehydration and potoential infection.
   - Hold anti-hypertensives for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: On TF at nursing home. Currently NPO.
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:23 AM
   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition: ICU
Summary:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, and altered mental status. The patient was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and was started on invasive ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/49 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy at a flow rate of 50% and is on a ventilator with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's physical examination reveals a chronically ill appearance with poor dentition, tracheostomy in place, and dry mucous membranes. The patient has a sacral pressure ulcer and flexion contractures at the ankles. The patient's neurological examination shows a decreased level of consciousness, no spontaneous movement, and normal tone.

The patient has several medical complications, including respiratory failure, altered mental status, vomiting, elevated cardiac enzymes, acute renal failure, anemia, and hypertension. The patient is at risk for further complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and stress ulcers.

The patient's treatment plan includes empiric VAP therapy, aggressive pulmonary toilet, weaning of FiO2, and neuro consult. The patient is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

The patient's code status is FULL, and the disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and transfered to the ICU for hypoxia and altered mental status. She is currently on invasive ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and has been weaned from 100% FiO2 overnight. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/49 mmHg. She has a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, anemia, and elevated cardiac enzymes. She has a history of vomiting, altered mental status, and acute renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may worsen due to her chronic ventilator dependence and the recent exacerbation from vomiting and aspiration.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to hypoxia, infection, or underlying seizure disorder, which may require further evaluation and management.
3. Vomiting: The patient's vomiting may lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and aspiration, which may require aggressive bowel regimen and close monitoring.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen due to pre-renal etiology, dehydration, and poor intake, which may require close monitoring of serum creatinine and urine output.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to dehydration, volume contraction, or underlying chronic disease, which may require close monitoring of hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen due to dehydration, infection, and chronic hypertension, which may require close monitoring and management.
7. Infection: The patient's recent exacerbation may be due to infection, which may require further evaluation and management.
8. Cardiac Enzyme Elevation: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may be due to acute ischemia or chronic disease, which may require further evaluation and management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue invasive ventilation and wean FiO2 as tolerated.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and vital signs closely.
3. Aggressively manage the patient's vomiting with bowel regimen and close monitoring.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and urine output closely.
5. Continue IV fluids and electrolyte replacement as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and hematocrit levels closely.
7. Manage the patient's hypertension with close monitoring and medication as needed.
8. Evaluate the patient for infection and manage accordingly.
9. Continue cardiac enzyme monitoring and management as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and hypoxia. She was transferred to the ICU for altered mental status and is currently on invasive ventilation. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/49 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99%. She is receiving 50% FiO2 and is on a ventilator with a set tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's physical examination reveals a chronically ill appearance, with poor dentition, a tracheostomy in place, and dry mucous membranes. Her cardiovascular examination is normal, with a widely split second heart sound. Her abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen, firm stool-filled colon, and heparin injection bruises. Her neurological examination reveals a decreased level of consciousness, with no response to verbal commands, but she does respond to noxious stimuli. She has increased tone with cogwheeling/rigidity and right CN VII palsy.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated cardiac enzymes, anemia, and acute renal failure. Her white blood cell count is 13.5 x 10^9/L, and her platelet count is 272 x 10^9/L. Her troponin-T level is 0.39 ng/mL, and her creatinine level is 137 umol/L. 

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology, which is likely exacerbated by vomiting, aspiration, and inability to clear secretions.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is unclear, and it is difficult to determine whether it is due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder.
3. Vomiting: The patient is unable to assess pain due to altered mental status, and her abdominal examination shows distension and firm stool-filled colon.
4. Elevated cardiac enzymes: The patient's elevated troponin-T level is unlikely to represent acute ischemia, and it is likely due to hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake, and she is being treated with IV fluids and monitored for volume status.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to dehydration/volume contraction, and she is being treated with IV fluids and monitored for Hct levels.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely due to dehydration and potential infection, and she is being monitored for changes in blood pressure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Empiric VAP therapy for now, with a plan to discontinue antibiotics if no growth is seen.
2. Chest PT and aggressive pulmonary toilet to manage respiratory secretions.
3. Weaning FiO2 by O2 sats to manage oxygen therapy.
4. Neuro consult to evaluate the patient's altered mental status.
5. Aggressive bowel regimen to manage vomiting and constipation.
6. Repeat EKG to monitor cardiac enzymes.
7. Continue IV fluids to manage dehydration and potential infection.
8. Renally dose medications to manage anemia and acute renal failure.
9. Monitor volume status and adjust treatment plan as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with chronic respiratory failure on ventilation, seizure disorder, and recent neurologic decline of unclear etiology. She was admitted after tube feed aspiration and witnessed seizures. The patient had a PEA arrest the day prior due to hypoxemia and mucous plugging. She is currently on invasive ventilation with FiO2 weaned from 100% to 50%. The patient is hemodynamically stable, but has decreased mental status, tremors, and facial droop. Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.5, hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 272 K/uL. Imaging studies reveal a right-sided effusion and retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure/Aspiration: The patient's respiratory failure and aspiration can lead to further respiratory compromise, pneumonia, and sepsis.
2. Autonomic Dysfunction Syndrome (AMS): The patient's AMS can lead to further neurological decline, cardiac instability, and increased risk of aspiration.
3. Vomiting: The patient's vomiting can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and aspiration.
4. s/p PEA Arrest: The patient's PEA arrest can lead to further cardiac instability, arrhythmias, and decreased cardiac output.
5. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's ARF can lead to further electrolyte imbalance, fluid overload, and decreased cardiac output.
6. Code Status Discussion: The patient's code status discussion with her husband and family highlights the importance of end-of-life care planning and the need for open communication.

Key Concerns:

* The patient's respiratory status, as evidenced by her continued need for invasive ventilation and decreased mental status.
* The patient's neurological status, as evidenced by her decreased mental status, tremors, and facial droop.
* The patient's cardiac status, as evidenced by her recent PEA arrest and need for ongoing cardiac monitoring.
* The patient's electrolyte imbalance, as evidenced by her decreased platelet count and potential for further electrolyte imbalance.
* The patient's fluid status, as evidenced by her ongoing fluid administration and potential for fluid overload.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of chronic respiratory failure, seizure disorder, and recent neurologic decline of unclear etiology. She was admitted following tube feed aspiration and witnessed seizures. The patient has experienced a PEA arrest, which was likely due to hypoxemia and mucous plugging.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on invasive ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and is hemodynamically stable.
* Neurologic status: The patient is not responsive, has a right facial droop, and does not follow simple commands. She responds to noxious stimuli but is not oriented.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a normal sinus rhythm, and her blood pressure is within normal limits.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury, which is likely pre-renal and improving with IV fluids.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a history of constipation and is at risk for vomiting. She has been placed on an aggressive bowel regimen and her tube feed has been held until her bowels are moving.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to continued hypoxemia and mucous plugging
* Neurologic deterioration due to underlying etiology of seizure disorder or aspiration
* Cardiovascular instability due to hypoxemia and mucous plugging
* Renal failure due to continued pre-renal injury
* Gastrointestinal complications due to constipation and potential vomiting
* Sepsis due to potential underlying infection

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Empiric antibiotics for possible infection
* Aggressive bowel regimen to manage constipation and prevent vomiting
* IV fluids to manage acute kidney injury
* Close monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status
* Neurologic consultation to guide baseline and prognosis
* Code status: Full code

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with chronic respiratory failure, seizure disorder, and recent neurological decline of unclear etiology. She was admitted after tube feed aspiration and witnessed seizures. She had a PEA arrest due to hypoxemia and mucous plugging. She is currently on invasive ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and is hemodynamically stable.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C
* Heart rate: 79 bpm
* Blood pressure: 129/96 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Tremulous, right facial droop, and non-responsive
* Coarse breath sounds anteriorly bilaterally
* Soft, non-tender, and hypoactive bowel sounds
* Trace pedal edema bilaterally and multiple ecchymoses
* Increased tone

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.5 K/μL
* Hematocrit: 30.1%
* Platelet count: 272 K/μL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.39 ng/mL
* C-reactive protein: 28.2 mg/L

Imaging studies reveal:

* Right-sided effusion and retrocardiac opacity on chest X-ray

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure/aspiration: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and recent aspiration may lead to further respiratory compromise.
2. Acute medication syndrome (AMS): The patient's neurological decline and recent seizure activity may be related to AMS, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including medication toxicity or electrolyte imbalance.
3. Vomiting: The patient's constipation and gas-filled bowel on KUB may lead to further vomiting and dehydration.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's recent PEA arrest and hypoxemia may have contributed to AKI, which could be pre-renal in origin.
5. Sepsis: The patient's recent aspiration and witnessed seizures may have led to sepsis, which could be life-threatening.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address the underlying causes of her neurological decline and to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Currently gas exchanging well on home vent settings.
   Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and
   inability to clear secretions.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Empiric VAP therapy for now, if no growth, will dc antibiotics
   (vanc/zosyn) in am tomorrow.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult this AM
   - Continue dilatin at prior dosing
   # Vomiting: Unable to assess pain currently given altered mental
   status. Abdominal exam most notable for distension and firm stool
   filled colon in LLQ. KUB showing air throughout colon without evidence
   obstruction.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG this AM
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to admission
   at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of
   poor intake.  Patient appears dry on exam.  Chronically with foley so
   unlikely obstruction.
   - Will trend Cr
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
    # Anemia: Currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Currently normotensive although in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection.
   - Hold anti-hypertensives for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and continues to require ventilator support. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 162/64 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes a ventilator mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, with a Vt of 450 mL, RR of 14, and FiO2 of 50%. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin levels, with a normal blood urea nitrogen and creatinine.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may progress, potentially leading to increased risk of falls, aspiration, and other complications.
3. Vomiting and aspiration: The patient's vomiting and aspiration may lead to further respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances and potential complications such as seizures and cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen, potentially leading to complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, stroke, and renal damage.
6. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and troponin levels may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
7. Seizure disorder: The patient's history of seizure disorder may lead to seizures, potentially compromising her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
8. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's critical illness myopathy may worsen, potentially leading to muscle weakness, respiratory failure, and other complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Currently gas exchanging well on home vent settings.
   Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by aspiration and
   inability to clear secretions.  Per 1 son pt was tolerating hours of
   [**Name (NI) **] at NH.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs,  unlikely to be pathogen
   - will d/c VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, attempt mode change/PS trial today, RSBI in am
   128.
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, pt may have missed a
   dose, will check a level on Monday
   - Start Keppra
   -EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting: Had KUB yesterday which showed stool in [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have
   been worsening residuals, vomiting and risk for aspiration. S/p
   aggressive bowel regimen with passage of large BM.
   -Continue to hold TF for now.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG this AM no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to admission
   at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Likely from pre-renal etiology in the setting of
   poor intake.  Patient appears dry on exam.  Chronically with foley so
   unlikely obstruction.
   - Will trend Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
    # Anemia: Currently elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Was hypertensive
   today to 170s systolic, was restarted on some of her home meds
   -labetalol 800TID, clonidine, will hold starting home metoprolol for
   now and monitor, consider adding back on in am.
   ICU Care

   concern of vomiting, aspiration.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.5, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 24 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 104 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 162/64 mmHg, and her heart rate is 83 beats per minute. Her electrocardiogram (EKG) shows a sinus rhythm.
* Neurological: The patient's neurological status is altered, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. She is not attentive, does not follow simple commands, and responds only to noxious stimuli. Her brainstem reflexes are intact, but her cranial nerves are abnormal, with a right CN VII palsy.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26.8 mg/dL. She has a Foley catheter in place, and her urine output is 869 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has been NPO for the past 24 hours due to vomiting and risk of aspiration. She has a distended abdomen, and her bowel sounds are sluggish. Her stool is firm and filled with heparin injection bruises.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.5 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 272 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.39 ng/mL
* C-reactive protein (CRP): 141 mg/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure
* Altered mental status
* Vomiting
* Elevated cardiac enzymes
* Acute renal failure
* Anemia
* Hypertension

The patient's medications include:

* Piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Vancomycin
* Levetiracetam
* Lorazepam
* Ondansetron
* Acetaminophen
* Ferrous sulfate
* Carbidopa-levodopa
* Tobramycin-dexamethasone eye ointment
* Folic acid
* Ranitidine
* Thiamine
* ASA
* Docusate
* Senna

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Renal failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Pneumonia
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Encephalopathy
* Seizures

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation with weaning attempts
* Continue antibiotics and antifungal medications
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotics accordingly
* Continue to monitor cardiac enzymes and adjust medications as necessary
* Continue to monitor renal function and adjust medications as necessary
* Continue to monitor gastrointestinal status and adjust medications as necessary
* Continue to monitor neurological status and adjust medications as necessary
* Consider EEG monitoring to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus
* Consider imaging studies to rule out pneumonia or other underlying conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on ventilatory support, and the underlying respiratory failure of unclear etiology may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or underlying seizure disorder. The EEG monitoring did not capture any convulsive activity, but the patient's mental status has not improved despite treatment.
3. Vomiting: The patient's vomiting may lead to further dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening complications such as aspiration pneumonia.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen due to pre-renal etiology, dehydration, and poor intake. Monitoring of volume status and IVF will be crucial to prevent further complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to dehydration and volume contraction, leading to potential complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen due to dehydration, infection, and potential volume overload, leading to further cardiovascular complications.
7. Infection: The patient's infection may worsen due to underlying respiratory failure, vomiting, and poor intake, leading to further systemic complications.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's distended abdomen and firm stool-filled colon may lead to further gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.
9. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate ongoing cardiac damage, and further cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest may occur.
10. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen due to ongoing encephalopathy, leading to further neurological deficits or even brain death.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to address these potential complications promptly and prevent further deterioration.

   -Will try PSV wean today
   -If RSBI favorable will trial brief (30 minute) trach mask trial today
   -Will need to check parameters (nif/VC/Compliance/Resistance) if
   failure seen to better define this source.
   -Will D/C abx as do not have evolution of evidence of significant
   infection and likely have aspiration pneumonitis only
   Seizure Disorder-The reported activity prior to admission is suggested
   to be seizure activity.  Here there has been minimal evidence of
   ongoing insult and EEG findings fail to show this as well which is
   reassuring.
   -Will continue Keppra per neurology team rec
   -Continue to monitor for seizure activity
   -Will continue Dilantin dosing as well.
   Hypertension
Chronic issue and medications held which will be
   re-started given hemodynamic stability.
   -Will re-start Clonidine today

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female admitted to the ICU with concerns for seizure onset and respiratory failure. She has a history of chronic respiratory failure and was admitted with hypoxia and altered mental status.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 155/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.5, hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, platelet count of 272, and creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL. Her troponin-T level is 0.39, and her troponin-I level is 0.12. She has a history of chronic respiratory failure and was admitted with concern for seizure onset.

The patient's medical history includes chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, and a seizure disorder. She has a history of aspiration events and has had intermittent trach mask trials at her facility.

The patient's current medications include ranitidine, heparin sodium, and Keppra, which were initiated by the neurology team. She is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics, including piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent ventilatory failure and intermittent trach mask trials at her facility make her at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of seizure disorder and is at risk for seizure activity.
3. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is at risk for further complications if not properly managed.
4. Aspiration pneumonitis: The patient has a history of aspiration events and is at risk for aspiration pneumonitis.
5. Bloodstream infections: The patient is at risk for bloodstream infections due to her central venous catheter and the use of prophylactic antibiotics.
6. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to her chronic respiratory failure and the use of mechanical ventilation.
7. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she is at risk for acute kidney injury.

In conclusion, the patient is a 76-year-old female admitted to the ICU with concerns for seizure onset and respiratory failure. She has a history of chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, and a seizure disorder. She is at risk for various medical complications, including respiratory failure, seizure disorder, hypertension, aspiration pneumonitis, bloodstream infections, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury.

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP since yesterday at 1:00pm.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs,  unlikely to be pathogen
   - Will d/c VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today ([**11-22**]), RSBI this am
   110.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, pt may have missed a
   dose, will check a level on Monday
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting: Had KUB yesterday which showed stool in [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have
   been worsening residuals, vomiting and risk for aspiration. S/p
   aggressive bowel regimen with passage of large BM.
   -Continue to hold TF for now.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on home
   meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will restart home lopressor given
   persistent HTN.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Still NPO for now given regurgitation, consider trial of trophic feeds
   today
   Glycemic Control:  Adequate
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:21 AM
   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence, and chronic respiratory failure. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and altered mental status. She is currently on CPAP/PSV and is tolerating it well. She has been experiencing vomiting, which has led to aspiration and inability to clear secretions. She has also had elevated cardiac enzymes, which are likely due to hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions. Her renal function has improved with hydration, and she is no longer in acute renal failure. She has anemia and hypertension, which are being managed accordingly.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may worsen due to her chronic condition and recent exacerbation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's recent respiratory failure and aspiration may lead to pneumonia, which could worsen her condition.
3. Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizure disorder and altered mental status may indicate a risk of seizure activity, which could worsen her condition.
4. Infection: The patient's recent fever and leukocytosis may indicate an infection, which could worsen her condition.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiac complications, which could worsen her condition.
6. Renal failure: The patient's anemia and hypertension may indicate a risk of renal failure, which could worsen her condition.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's NPO status and potential for malnutrition may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could worsen her condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed.
2. Consider starting antibiotics for pneumonia if the patient's respiratory status worsens.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust therapy as needed.
4. Consider starting anticonvulsant therapy if the patient's seizure activity worsens.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Consider starting cardiac therapy if the patient's cardiac enzymes worsen.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider starting nutritional supplements if the patient's nutritional status worsens.

   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP since yesterday at 1:00pm.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs,  unlikely to be pathogen
   - Will d/c VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today ([**11-22**]), RSBI this am
   110.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic
   encephalopathy from infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level),
   hypoxia, or from underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status)
   though this was not captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in
   [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At
   that time, appears to have had similar mental/functional status that
   she has now; however, per notes and her son, had been making
   improvements since that time.  During her last admission, had extensive
   neuro work up at that time which was largely unrevealing including LP,
   paraneoplastic labs which were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG
   concerning for critical illness myopathy.  Patient does not appear to
   be in nonconvulsive status as she does react to noxious stimuli and
   appears to calm when addressed.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, pt may have missed a
   dose, will check a level on Monday
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting: Had KUB yesterday which showed stool in [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have
   been worsening residuals, vomiting and risk for aspiration. S/p
   aggressive bowel regimen with passage of large BM.
   -Continue to hold TF for now.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trending down overnight.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on home
   meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will restart home lopressor given
   persistent HTN.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Still NPO for now given regurgitation, consider trial of trophic feeds
   today
   Glycemic Control:  Adequate
   Lines:

   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:

   Disposition: ICU, screening for LTAC

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and hypoxia. The patient was transferred to the ICU for altered mental status and hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on CPAP/PSV and is tolerating it well. The RSBI is 116, which is concerning for underlying respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure is 160/75 mmHg, which is elevated. The patient has a history of hypertension, and the medication has been restarted.
* Neurological status: The patient has altered mental status, which is unclear whether it is due to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or the underlying seizure disorder. The patient does not appear to be in nonconvulsive status and reacts to noxious stimuli.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has been vomiting and has had worsening residuals, which has led to the risk of aspiration. The patient has been on an aggressive bowel regimen, and the Foley catheter has been held.
* Renal status: The patient has acute renal failure, which has resolved, likely due to pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake. The patient's creatinine level has improved since admission.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia, which is still elevated above the prior baseline of 25, suggesting dehydration/volume contraction.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's RSBI is concerning for underlying respiratory failure, which can lead to further decline in respiratory status.
* Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and fever may be indicative of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
* Aspiration: The patient's vomiting and risk of aspiration can lead to respiratory failure and pneumonia.
* Hypertension: The patient's elevated blood pressure can lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac failure or stroke.
* Renal failure: The patient's history of acute renal failure and continued dehydration can lead to further decline in renal function.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of vomiting and gastrointestinal bleeding can lead to further complications, such as hemorrhage or perforation.

The patient requires continued close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, gastrointestinal, and renal status to prevent further complications and improve their overall condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP since yesterday at 1:00pm.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs/GNR,  will continue to follow micro
   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA, growing what
   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today ([**11-22**]), did not tolerate
   [**4-22**], RSBI this am 110.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission.
   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection,
   drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from underlying
   seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not captured
   on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro ICU
   (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.
   During her last admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time
   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows
   commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, will check a level on
   Monday
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.
   - Will restart TF this morning and increase as tolerated to goal,
   continue to check for residuals.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trended down since admission.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.1 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue IVF for now.
   Continue to monitor volume status.
   - Renally dose meds
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on home
   meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will uptitrate clonidine today given
   persistent hypertension.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Still NPO for now given regurgitation, consider trial of trophic feeds
   today
   Glycemic Control:  Adequate
   Lines:

   22 Gauge - [**2115-4-12**] 04:24 AM

   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care
   Comments:

   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU, screening for LTAC<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently receiving CPAP/PSV respiratory support. Her vital signs are stable, but she has ongoing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and potential complications such as vomiting, regurgitation, and elevated cardiac enzymes.

Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure is likely due to an unclear etiology, but recent exacerbation may be related to vomiting, aspiration, and inability to clear secretions.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved since admission, but the cause is unclear and may be related to generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from infection, drugs, hypoxia, or her underlying seizure disorder.
3. Vomiting/Regurgitation: The patient has had KUB showing stool in the rectum, and regurgitation has worsened residuals, vomiting, and aspiration. Aggressive bowel regimen and BMs are being used to manage this issue.
4. Elevated Cardiac Enzymes: The patient's elevated troponins are likely due to hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions, and have trended down since admission.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, likely due to pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is still elevated above her prior baseline, suggesting dehydration/volume contraction.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely related to breathing trials and has been managed with BP meds.

Plan:

1. Continue respiratory support with CPAP/PSV and wean FIO2 as tolerated.
2. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust respiratory support accordingly.
3. Continue to manage altered mental status with continued dilantin and Keppra.
4. Aggressively manage vomiting and regurgitation with bowel regimen and BMs.
5. Continue to monitor cardiac enzymes and adjust medication as needed.
6. Monitor renal function and adjust IVF as needed.
7. Monitor anemia and adjust IVF as needed.
8. Manage hypertension with labetalol and clonidine.
9. Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and altered mental status. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and was found to have respiratory failure of unclear etiology. She is currently on CPAP/PSV and tolerating it well. The patient has had multiple medical complications, including vomiting and regurgitation, which has led to worsening residuals and aspiration. She has also had elevated cardiac enzymes, acute renal failure, and anemia. The patient's mental status has improved significantly since admission, but she still has encephalopathic changes on EEG.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may continue to worsen if not properly managed.
2. VAP (Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia): The patient's sputum culture grew oral flora, which may indicate VAP.
3. Seizure Disorder: The patient's seizure disorder may be exacerbated by her underlying medical conditions and medications.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and fever may indicate an underlying infection, which needs to be treated promptly.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiac damage, which needs to be monitored closely.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not properly managed.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's encephalopathic changes on EEG may indicate a neurological complication, which needs to be monitored closely.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's vomiting and regurgitation may lead to further complications, such as aspiration and malnutrition.
9. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure and cardiac arrest.
10. Infections: The patient's chronic medical conditions and immunosuppressive medications may increase her risk of infections, such as pneumonia and urinary tract infections.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence. She was admitted for hypoxemia, altered mental status, and aspiration pneumonitis. She has been on mechanical ventilation and has been weaned to a successful trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV). Her respiratory status has improved, and she is now on CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 171/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 98% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 13.5 K/uL
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.39 ng/mL
* TCO2: 28 mmHg
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is notable for tracheostomy in place, normal pulse, and diminished breath sounds. Her abdominal examination is soft, and her extremities show 1+ edema.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is being weaned from mechanical ventilation and will continue to follow culture results in setting of antibiotics discontinued.
* Seizure: The patient will continue on Keppra and Dilantin, and her exam is much improved.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's kidney function is improving with adequate fluid support and patient moving to baseline clearance by creatinine.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is controlled with labetolol, and she will move to patient home dosing and return clonidine as next [**Doctor Last Name**] from home dosing.
* ICU-patient: The patient is stable and reasonable to consider transfer to facility for chronic ventilatory unit.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, atelectasis, or respiratory acidosis can occur if the patient is not weaned from mechanical ventilation properly.
* Seizure: Seizure activity can recur if the patient's medication is not adjusted properly.
* Acute renal failure: Kidney function can deteriorate if the patient's fluid status is not monitored closely.
* Hypertension: Blood pressure can increase if the patient is not properly managed with medication.
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, and her respiratory status is improving. However, she is still at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent these complications from occurring.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence who was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and altered mental status. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 27 and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 154/75 mmHg. She has a tracheostomy in place and is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.

The patient's neurological status is altered, with no response to commands, right CNVII palsy, and a sacral pressure ulcer/skin tear. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin-T, as well as abnormal liver function tests and electrolyte imbalances.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a respiratory rate of 27 and oxygen saturation of 100%. She may be at risk for respiratory failure, pneumonia, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is altered, with no response to commands and right CNVII palsy. She may be at risk for further neurological deterioration, including brain injury or stroke.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and she may be at risk for cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, or heart failure.
4. Infection: The patient is receiving antibiotics, but she may still be at risk for infection, including sepsis, pneumonia, and catheter-associated urinary tract infections.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal examination is abnormal, with a soft, distended abdomen and heparin bruises. She may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction, or perforation.
6. Skin and wound complications: The patient has a sacral pressure ulcer/skin tear, which may become infected or worsen if not properly managed.
7. Nutritional complications: The patient is receiving nutrition, but her nutritional status may be compromised due to her altered mental status and inability to eat.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications and improve her outcome.

   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP.  This AM on [**9-22**], and
   adjusted to [**4-22**].  Will attempt a trial of trach mask.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs/GNR,  will continue to follow micro
   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA, growing what
   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today, follow RISBI.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline.   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from
   infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from
   underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not
   captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro
   ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.
   During her last admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time
   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows
   commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, -> level subtherapeutic
   this AM, d/w neuro and will give 1x loading dose today.
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   .
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.  Will start reglan standing and senna to assist
   with BM
s and avoid precipitating further aspiration.
   - Will restart TF this morning and increase as tolerated to goal,
   continue to check for residuals.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trended down since admission.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.0 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue tube feeds for
   now. Continue to monitor volume status.
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on some
   home meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will restart metoprolol as taking as
   outpatient. Follow.
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of seizure disorder, chronic ventilator dependence, and chronic vent dependence. She was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and altered mental status. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on CPAP/PSV ventilation and is tolerating it well. However, she has had recent exacerbations of respiratory failure, likely due to vomiting and aspiration. A trial of a trach mask is planned.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has improved since admission, but the underlying cause is unclear. She may have generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy due to infection, drugs, hypoxia, or her underlying seizure disorder. A neuro consult has recommended continuing dilantin and starting Keppra.
* Vomiting/regurgitation: The patient has had KUB showing stool in the rectum, which has led to worsening residuals, vomiting, and aspiration. An aggressive bowel regimen has been started, and regurgitation has improved. Reglan and senna will be started to assist with bowel movements and avoid further aspiration.
* Elevated cardiac enzymes: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, but this is unlikely to represent acute ischemia given the unchanged EKG. The elevated levels may be due to hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions. Aspirin will be continued.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, likely due to pre-renal etiology in the setting of poor intake. Her creatinine levels have improved since admission.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is still elevated above her prior baseline, suggesting dehydration/volume contraction. Her Hct levels will be trended, and IVF will be continued as needed.
* Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is mostly a problem during breathing trials. Her blood pressure has improved with the restart of home medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's recent exacerbations of respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Infection: The patient's altered mental status and elevated cardiac enzymes may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's regurgitation and vomiting may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen her respiratory status and overall condition.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated cardiac enzymes and hypertension may indicate underlying cardiac issues, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
* Renal complications: The patient's anemia and potential dehydration may lead to further renal compromise, potentially resulting in acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and potential seizure disorder may lead to further neurological complications, such as status epilepticus, encephalopathy, or even brain death.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old woman with a history of seizure disorder and chronic ventilator dependence, admitted for increased hypoxemia and altered mental status. The patient has improved from acute decompensation, with likely aspiration pneumonitis as the cause. She has been weaned to low-grade PSV requirement, and her pulmonary compliance has improved.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F)
* Heart rate: 91 bpm (80-91)
* Blood pressure: 154/75 mmHg (95) {139/60 (78) - 178/84 (105)}
* Respiratory rate: 32 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient is receiving respiratory support with a ventilator in CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 300 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 13.5 K/uL
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.39 ng/mL
* Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.5 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: Aspiration pneumonitis is suspected as the cause, and the patient is being weaned from ventilator support.
* Seizure disorder: The patient is receiving current antiepileptic medications, and neurology consultation is planned.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function is improving.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is still high, and metoprolol will be added back into her regimen.
* ICU care: The patient is receiving nutrition through a tube feeding, and her blood sugar is well-controlled. She is at risk for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcer, and prophylaxis is being provided.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, requiring increased ventilator support or mechanical ventilation.
* Seizure disorder: The patient's seizure disorder may worsen, requiring adjustments to her antiepileptic medications or further neurology consultation.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function may continue to decline, requiring further management and potential dialysis.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure may continue to be elevated, requiring further management and potential adjustments to her medications.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly given her chronic ventilator dependence and potential aspiration pneumonitis.
* Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis, particularly given her immobility and chronic illness.
* Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer, particularly given her chronic illness and potential aspiration pneumonitis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure of 144/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.5-8.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.1-8.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 272-230 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3-1.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.39 ng/mL
* Glucose: 101-70 mg/dL
* Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.5 mg/dL

The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level of 3.7 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's intubation and tracheostomy, and therefore, peripheral vascular, skin, and neurologic examinations were not assessed.

The patient's medical history is significant for weakness, and a nerve biopsy is planned to determine the cause of the weakness. The patient's medications include hydralazine and atropine, which were started to manage hypertension and bradycardia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Stress ulcer bleeding
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to the patient's glucose levels
* Electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia
* Infection due to the patient's immunosuppressed state
* Further decline in renal function or cardiac function

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   76 year old with history a seizure disorder, chronic vent dependence
   transfered for hypoxia, and altered mental status.
   # Respiratory Failure: Underlying respiratory failure of unclear
   etiology given prior evaluation was only revealing for critical illness
   neuropathy. Recent exacerbation likely from vomiting complicated by
   aspiration and inability to clear secretions.  Per son pt was
   tolerating hours of [**Name (NI) **] at NH. Currently gas exchanging well on home
   vent settings. Has been tolerating PSV/CPAP.  This AM on [**9-22**], and
   adjusted to [**4-22**].  Will attempt a trial of trach mask.
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures drawn, no growth on urine or blood,
   sputum with 1+ GPRs/GNR,  will continue to follow micro
   - D/c
d VAP coverage with Vanc/Zosyn given lack of culture data,
   fevers, leukocytosis, radiographic evidence for PNA, growing what
   appears to be oral flora in sputum culture.
   - Chest PT, aggressive pulmonary toilet
   - Wean FIO2 by O2sats, continue PS trial today, follow RISBI.
   - Can attempt short trial of trach mask today if patient can tolerate.
   # Altered Mental Status: Siginificantly improved since admission and at
   baseline.   Unclear if generalized toxic metabolic encephalopathy from
   infection, drugs (mildly elevated dilantin level), hypoxia, or from
   underlying seizure disorder (non-convulsive status) though this was not
   captured on EEG monitoring during last admission in [**Month (only) 1563**] to the Neuro
   ICU (showed only encephalopathic background).  At that time, appears to
   have had similar mental/functional status that she has now; however,
   per notes and her son, had been making improvements since that time.
   During her last admission, had extensive neuro work up at that time
   which was largely unrevealing including LP, paraneoplastic labs which
   were negative, SPEP/UPEP, MRI/MRA brain, EMG concerning for critical
   illness myopathy.  Patient is currently interactive and follows
   commands.
   - Neuro consult recommends continuing dilantin, -> level subtherapeutic
   this AM, d/w neuro and will give 1x loading dose today.
   - Started Keppra
   - EEG shows encephalopathy without epileptiform activity.
   .
   # Vomiting/regurgitation: Had KUB on admission showing stool in the
   [**Last Name (LF) 800**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] have led to worsening residuals, vomiting and aspiration.
   S/p aggressive bowel regimen with BM at this time.  Regurgitation also
   improved at this time.  Will start reglan standing and senna to assist
   with BM
s and avoid precipitating further aspiration.
   - Will restart TF this morning and increase as tolerated to goal,
   continue to check for residuals.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen, currently having BMs
   # Elevated cardiac enzymes: Unlikely to represent acute ischemia given
   unchanged EKG from prior.  Multiple reasons for elevated troponins
   including hypoxic/PEA arrest and chest compressions per report.
   Trended down since admission.
   - Repeat EKG with no change
   - Continue aspirin
   - DC'd plavix given rule out as this was started just prior to
   admission at her nursing home.
   # Acute renal failure: Resolved. Likely from pre-renal etiology in the
   setting of poor intake.  Patient initally appeared quite dry on exam.
   Chronically with foley so unlikely obstruction.
   - Trending Cr, improvement since admission from 1.5 to 1.0 with
   hydration
   - IVF with some improvement in BUN/Cr, will continue tube feeds for
   now. Continue to monitor volume status.
   # Anemia: Still elevated above prior baseline of 25 suggesting
   dehydration/volume contraction.
   - Trend Hct
   - IVF prn as above.
   # Hypertension: Per history hypertension mostly a problem during
   breathing trials. Was initially normotensive in the setting of
   dehydration and potential infection so BP meds held.  Restarted on some
   home meds with some improvement in blood pressure.
   - Labetalol 800 TID, clonidine, will restart metoprolol as taking as
   outpatient. Follow.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
